Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Computing Education through Synergistic Support (ACESS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Advancing Computing Education through Synergistic Support (ACESS) program at Winston-Salem State University provides financial support for highly qualified, though economically disadvantaged, students to enroll in and complete Computer Science and Information Technology BS degree programs. Scholarships are also offered to undergraduates majoring in chemistry, biology or mathematics who minor in computer science or information technology. The program also seeks to enroll women and students with disabilities.

ACESS Scholars receive mentoring from both faculty and upper level students. They are encouraged to participate in research experiences and receive financial support to attend at least one annual conference. Many present the results of their research experiences at regional and/or national conferences. ACESS Scholars receive career counseling and attend at least one job fair. Most ACESS Scholars develop additional professional skills by participating in local chapters of computing organizations such as the ACM, National Society of Black Engineers, or the Society of Women Engineers; or they join the Game Programming Club or the Robotics Group.

Offered by a Historically Black College and University (HBCU), the ACESS program increases the number of highly trained, underrepresented computing professionals as well as developing a new generation of computer science and information technology leaders and researchers.

Institution.Name: Winston-Salem State University
Institution.StreetAddress: 601 S Martin Luther King Jr Dr

Performance_Institution.Name: Winston-Salem State University
Performance_Institution.StreetAddress: 601 S Martin Luther King Jr Dr

POR.DRECONTENT:
Advancing Computing Education through Synergistic Support  (ACESS)

 OUTCOMES REPORT 1060447  

The goal of the Advancing Computing Education through Synergistic Support (ACESS) Scholarship Program supported academically talented but economically disadvantaged students, while serving as a catalyst for revitalizing interest in Computer Science through a program of scholarships, mentoring, enrichment, interdisciplinary collaboration, and leadership activities. ACESS scholarship recipients received tuition assistance and an opportunity to participate in many activities of the program.  Program activities focused on building strong computing skills and using the synergy of those skills to solve science and industry problems in the classroom and via research participation.

The ACESS Program was very successful in providing financial support for highly qualified, yet economically disadvantaged, students to enroll and complete the BS in Computer Science, BS in Information Technology or MS in Computer Science and Information Technology. Over thirty students were served.

Retention of ACESS Scholars was maintained at 86% over the funding period. This was a major success because the retention rate for the university was 78% and it was even lower for STEM disciplines.  An added benefit was the motivation of students to improve their grade point average in an attempt to compete for the highly publicized scholarship. Additionally the program was successful in motivating students to improve their undergraduate grade point average to qualify for the Master's degree program.  All MS scholarship awards were made to students who matriculated in the undergraduate program without an ACESS scholarship, but who improved their performance by graduation to qualify for an award to enroll in the graduate program.  These students were also mentors to ACESS scholars.  

The ACESS Scholars Program's success with the development of professional "soft skills" by providing enrichment activities to enhance communication and leadership, as well as outreach to other undergraduates and K-12 students.  Results of the program was the addition of a Professional Development Seminar which is now required of all Computer Science and Information Technology majors.  Outreach activities included "CS/IT Majors" presentations for undecided freshmen and sophomores as well as outreach to all Winston-Salem Forsyth Middle Grades students during the annual fall Robotics Competition.

The program was initially designed to provide 12 students full scholarships over a 4-year period.   However, we provided thirty-five scholarships over a 4, 3, 2, or 1 year period.  Some students did not have unmet need to qualify for a full scholarship and those funds were used to award partial scholarships to additional students.  

The ACESS Scholars program was a huge success and met the goals of the project (funding, academic performance enhancement, and professional development).  The attached images show the ACESS Scholars engaged in activities associated with the program.
